title: Area of a triangle
summary: Calculating the area of a triangle is an elementary problem encountered often in many different situations. The best known and simplest formula is T = b h / 2 , {\displaystyle T=bh/2,} where b is the length of the base of the triangle, and h is the height or altitude of the triangle. The term "base" denotes any side, and "height" denotes the length of a perpendicular from the vertex opposite the base onto the line containing the base. In 499 CE Aryabhata, used this illustrated method in the Aryabhatiya (section 2.6).[1]
